caption.body: California Arts & Architecture began in 1929 as a magazine for residential design featuring a wide range of styles from Tudor to Mediterranean. When it declared bankruptcy in 1938, the magazine was purchased by John Entenza who transformed it into a modernist haven for design. When Charles and Ray Eames relocated to Los Angeles in 1941, they became friends with Entenza. Ray designed twenty-six covers for Arts & Architecture between 1942 and 1947. Her cover designs highlighted her interest in collage, biomorphic and geometric forms, and pops of color.  See “California Modernist Women: Groundbreaking Creativity” on display, post-security, in Harvey Milk Terminal 1. https://bit.ly/CaliforniaModernistWomen
